abstractContent.text: The following paper presents a further extension of the Suggested Upper Merged Ontology (SUMO), i. e. the development of default physical measurements for most of its classes (Artifacts, Devices, Objects) and respective children.
The extension represents an arbitrary , computable and reproducible approximation of defaults for upper and middle-level concepts.
The paper illustrates advantages of such extension, challenges encountered during the compilation, related work and future research.

introductionContent.text: Over the last fourteen years SUMO) has been developed into a large, general-domain ontology, which currently 1 includes 20,000 terms and 80,000 axioms stated in higherorder logic.
SUMO provides an open source environment for the development of logical theories called SIGMA.
This enables the manipulation of different formal languages (including TPTP and OWL),).
Among them, the logical formal language SUO-KIF has been selected for the development of knowledge-based (or KB) terms, through which SUMO can be searched.
Another possible search of terms in SUMO is via the Princeton WordNet ®, to which the ontology has been fully mapped.

In the first part of this paper, after introducing SUMO in generic terms, we explain the motivation behind the undergone extension of 300+ physical default measurements (the term 'default' is hereby used as synonym for 'approximation' or 'estimation').
The second part deals with the advantages and issues encountered during the compilation of the defaults, and presents some practical examples of defaults and higher-order annotation.
Related research and future work follow.
